natural problem: Find all real values of $x$ that satisfy $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \ge \frac23.$ (Give your answer in interval notation.)
natural solution: Moving all the terms to the left-hand side, we have \[\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} -\frac23 \ge 0.\]To solve this inequality, we find a common denominator: \[\frac{3(x+7) + 3 \cdot 3(x+1) - 2(x+1)(x+7)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0,\]which simplifies to \[-\frac{2(x+4)(x-2)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0.\]Therefore, we want the values of $x$ such that \[f(x) = \frac{(x+4)(x-2)}{(x+1)(x+7)} \le 0.\]To do this, we make the following sign table: \begin{tabular}{c|cccc|c} &$x+4$ &$x-2$ &$x+1$ &$x+7$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-7$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-7<x<-4$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-4<x<-1$ &$+$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<2$ &$+$&$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>2$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Because the inequality $f(x) \le 0$ is nonstrict, we must also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ which are $x=-4$ and $x=2.$ Putting it all together, the solutions to the inequality are \[x \in \boxed{(-7, -4] \cup (-1, 2]}.\]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ -7"
and h2 : "1/(x+1) + 3/(x+7) ≥ 2/3"
shows  "x ∈ {-7<..< -4} ∪ {-1<..<2}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all real values of $x$ that satisfy $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \ge \frac23.$ (Give your answer in interval notation.) The final Answer is (-7, -4] \cup (-1, 2]
 ### Proof
 Moving all the terms to the left-hand side, we have \[\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} -\frac23 \ge 0.\]To solve this inequality, we find a common denominator: \[\frac{3(x+7) + 3 \cdot 3(x+1) - 2(x+1)(x+7)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0,\]which simplifies to \[-\frac{2(x+4)(x-2)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0.\]Therefore, we want the values of $x$ such that \[f(x) = \frac{(x+4)(x-2)}{(x+1)(x+7)} \le 0.\]To do this, we make the following sign table: \begin{tabular}{c|cccc|c} &$x+4$ &$x-2$ &$x+1$ &$x+7$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-7$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-7<x<-4$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-4<x<-1$ &$+$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<2$ &$+$&$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>2$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Because the inequality $f(x) \le 0$ is nonstrict, we must also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ which are $x=-4$ and $x=2.$ Putting it all together, the solutions to the inequality are \[x \in \boxed{(-7, -4] \cup (-1, 2]}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x ≠ -1"
and h1 : "x ≠ -7"
and h2 : "1/(x+1) + 3/(x+7) ≥ 2/3"
shows  "x ∈ {-7<..< -4} ∪ {-1<..<2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the range of real numbers $x$ not equal to $-1$ and $-7$ such that $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \geq \frac{2}{3}$. The solution is $-7 < x < -4$ or $-1 < x < 2$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / (x + 1) + 3 / (x + 7) >= 2 / 3"
shows  "x \<in> {-7<..< -4} \<union> {-1<..<2}"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find all real values of $x$ that satisfy $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \ge \frac23.$ (Give your answer in interval notation.) The final Answer is (-7, -4] \cup (-1, 2]
 ### Proof
 Moving all the terms to the left-hand side, we have \[\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} -\frac23 \ge 0.\]To solve this inequality, we find a common denominator: \[\frac{3(x+7) + 3 \cdot 3(x+1) - 2(x+1)(x+7)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0,\]which simplifies to \[-\frac{2(x+4)(x-2)}{3(x+1)(x+7)} \ge 0.\]Therefore, we want the values of $x$ such that \[f(x) = \frac{(x+4)(x-2)}{(x+1)(x+7)} \le 0.\]To do this, we make the following sign table: \begin{tabular}{c|cccc|c} &$x+4$ &$x-2$ &$x+1$ &$x+7$ &$f(x)$ \\ \hline$x<-7$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-7<x<-4$ &$-$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$-4<x<-1$ &$+$&$-$&$-$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]$-1<x<2$ &$+$&$-$&$+$&$+$&$-$\\ [.1cm]$x>2$ &$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$&$+$\\ [.1cm]\end{tabular}Because the inequality $f(x) \le 0$ is nonstrict, we must also include the values of $x$ such that $f(x) = 0,$ which are $x=-4$ and $x=2.$ Putting it all together, the solutions to the inequality are \[x \in \boxed{(-7, -4] \cup (-1, 2]}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / (x + 1) + 3 / (x + 7) >= 2 / 3"
shows  "x \<in> {-7<..< -4} \<union> {-1<..<2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the range of values for $x$ that satisfy the inequality $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \geq \frac{2}{3}$. The solution is $x$ is in the interval from -7 to -4 (excluding -7 and -4) or the interval from -1 to 2 (excluding -1 and 2).

shows  "x \<in> {..< -4} \<union> {-1 <.. 2}"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> -7"
and h2 : "1 / (x + 1) + 3 / (x + 7) \<ge> 2 / 3"
shows  "(x > -7 \<and> x \<le> -4) \<or> (x > -1 \<and> x \<le> 2)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

assumes h0 : "x \<noteq> -1"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> -7"
and h2 : "1 / (x + 1) + 3 / (x + 7) \<ge> 2 / 3"
shows  "(x > -7 \<and> x \<le> -4) \<or> (x > -1 \<and> x \<le> 2)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / (x + 1) + 3 / (x + 7) \<ge> 2 / 3"
shows  "x \<in> {-7<..< -4} \<union> {-1<..<2}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Determine the range of $x$ that satisfies the inequality $\frac{1}{x+1} + \frac{3}{x+7} \geq \frac{2}{3}$. The final answer is $x$ is in the interval $(-7, -4)$ or $(-1, 2)$.
